channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Here is the latest.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Lydia DePillis

item.title: Cambodia Agrees to a Reduced Tariff and Breathes a Sigh of Relief
item.description: Initially 49%, it was lowered to 19%, easing worries of a damaging hit to the country’s garment and footwear production industries.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

item.title: South Korea Reaches Trade Deal With Trump
item.description: The agreement comes after other American allies, like Japan, clinched their own deals, partly to moderate President Trump’s tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: Countries Promise Trump to Buy U.S. Gas, and Leave the Details for Later
item.description: U.S. trading partners are committing to buy more gas than they need or than the U.S. can produce, at least in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Rebecca F. Elliott

item.title: Trump Targets Copper With Tariffs, Though Not as Aggressively as Expected
item.description: The president stopped short of putting a 50 percent tariff on refined copper, as he had threatened earlier this year. The market reaction was swift anyway and prices tumbled.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: See How Often Two Fed Governors Have Dissented on a Rate Change Vote
item.description: Two top Fed officials voted against the central bank’s decision to leave rates unchanged, the first dual dissent in more than 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Christine Zhang

item.title: I.M.F. Raises Global Growth Outlook as U.S. Eases Some Tariffs
item.description: The International Monetary Fund warned that trade tension continued to be a risk for the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Trump Is Winning His Trade War. What Will That Mean for the Economy?
item.description: The president’s vision for reshaping global trade is falling into place, but he is embarking on an experiment that economists say could still produce damaging results.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Who Pays for U.S. Tariffs, and Where Does the Money Go?
item.description: President Trump is seeking to raise federal revenue by imposing levies on goods from foreign nations. Here’s how the process works.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Visits Federal Reserve as Campaign Against Powell Intensifies
item.description: The administration has repeatedly criticized Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the central bank, for his handling of the economy and the cost of work on the institution’s headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Investment Fund Seals Trade Deal for Japan and Expands Trump’s Influence
item.description: President Trump will get to decide where to invest Japanese money and the United States will keep 90 percent of the profits, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are the Highest in a Century. But After His Threats, They Seem Like a Relief.
item.description: The president imposed tariffs on Japan, one of America’s closest allies, that would have been alarming just months ago. And markets went up.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Administration Keeps Pressure on Powell Over Rate Cuts and Renovations
item.description: President Trump and his top aides have criticized Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, for his management of both the economy and a $2.5 billion revamp of the central bank’s headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Trump Administration Keeps 19 Percent Tariff on Indonesia in Trade Deal
item.description: The administration provided some insight into the terms that were agreed upon between Indonesia and the United States, hinting at how other vague and hastily negotiated deals may turn out.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Philippines’ Leader Meets With Trump to Clinch Trade Deal
item.description: President Trump announced that he had secured a deal with the country that will leave a 19 percent tariff in place, though no details were immediately available.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Ana Swanson

item.title: As Trump Courts a More Assertive Beijing, China Hawks Are Losing Out
item.description: The Trump administration has dialed back aggressive measures against China and reversed its position on technology controls as the president angles for a Chinese trip later this year.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle

item.title: Trump Announces ‘Great Deal’ on Trade With Indonesia
item.description: President Trump said the agreement would partly walk back some of the steep tariffs he threatened on the country last week. Indonesia’s president called Mr. Trump a “tough negotiator.”
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alexandra Stevenson

item.title: Rising Inflation Underscores Risks in Trump’s New Tariff Threats
item.description: New data showing price increases last month could foreshadow even higher costs if the president imposes steep tariffs on Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Colby Smith

item.title: The Economy Has Been Resilient. The New Round of Tariffs May Hit Harder.
item.description: The economy’s resilience so far to President Trump’s global trade war risks emboldening him and unleashing the sort of economic devastation that economists have long feared.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm

item.title: Trump Adds 17% Tariff on Tomatoes From Mexico
item.description: The Trump administration is adding a 17 percent tariff to a year-round grocery store staple, while funneling more business to domestic tomato growers, largely in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
